author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Prosecutors Seek to Delay Trump Documents Trial to December
description: The special counsel argued that the August date set by the judge did not allow enough time to deal with the complications of classified evidence, but still proposed a relatively speedy timetable.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel, has asked a federal judge to move back the start of the trial of former President Donald J. Trump and his co-defendant, Walt Nauta, in the classified documents case from August to Dec. 11, according to a Justice Department filing made public late Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Harvard Scholar Who Studies Honesty Is Accused of Fabricating Findings
description: Questions about a widely cited paper are the latest to be raised about methods used in behavioral research.
content: Over the past two decades, dozens of behavioral scientists have risen to prominence pointing out the power of small interventions to improve well-being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Suspected Prigozhin Was Preparing to Take Military Action Against Russia
description: The information was considered both solid and alarming because of the possibility that a major nuclear-armed rival of the United States could descend into chaos.
content: American intelligence officials briefed senior military and administration officials on Wednesday that Yevgeny Prigozhin, the leader of the mercenary Wagner Group, was preparing to take military action against senior Russian defense officials, according to officials familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Sterling K. Brown Is on His Best Behavior, Just in Case
description: The Emmy-winning actor and star of the new movie “Biosphere” is sweet on vegan cookies, his Audi e-Tron and Toni Morrison’s “The Bluest Eye.”
content: The first time Sterling K. Brown read the script for “Biosphere,” his new sci-fi movie with Mark Duplass, he thought, “‘This is very non-Randall-esque,’ which is always one of the criteria that I’m looking for in the next project.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Rebel Wagner Forces, Threatening March to Moscow, Abruptly Stand Down
description: The mercenary group had seized the Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, the center of Moscow’s military operations in Ukraine, posing a grave threat to President Vladimir Putin’s government.
content: A domestic security crisis that threatened the government of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared to ease late Saturday, when a mercenary tycoon, whose forces had seized critical facilities in southern Russia and begun an armed march on Moscow, abruptly stood down after cutting a deal that allowed him and his fighters to escape prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mathew Brownstein
title: Living in a Barbie World, Through the Decades
description: A new project from the Real Estate desk uses stop-motion to take readers inside Barbie’s Dreamhouses.
content: One afternoon last summer, Anna Kodé, a reporter on the Real Estate desk at The New York Times, and Nikita Stewart, the desk’s editor, were talking about the upcoming “Barbie” film when, naturally, the conversation turned to Barbie’s personal pad, the Dreamhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni, Ravi Mattu and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Extreme Travel Is Inspiring New Types of Insurance
description: Some offer evacuations and others provide coverage for accidental death or injury to cater to the growing adventure tourism market.
content: The tragic deaths of five people on a tour to see the Titanic shipwreck this week have put the risks of extreme travel into focus. But despite the dangers, travel to out-there locations like the South Pole, remote mountaintops, shark-infested waters and space is becoming more popular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Intelligence Report Finds No Clear Evidence of Covid Origins in Wuhan Lab
description: A declassified report says that the illnesses of three laboratory researchers in 2019 do not support or refute the theory that the virus that causes Covid could have slipped out of a lab.
content: Intelligence agencies do not believe the case of three workers from a laboratory in Wuhan, China, who became ill in 2019 can help shed light on whether the Covid-19 pandemic originated from an accidental lab leak, according to a report made public Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Real Lesson From the Hunter Biden Saga
description: It isn’t about presidential corruption but a determined parent battling his son’s addiction with unconditional love.
content: One of our most urgent national problems is addiction to drugs and alcohol. It now kills about a quarter-million Americans a year, leaves many others homeless and causes unimaginable heartache in families across the country — including the family living in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: Want to Avoid a Rainy Ceremony? This Weather Expert Can Help.
description: If you’re planning a wedding, Andrew Leavitt can help you bypass snowstorms, avoid wet feet during high tides and pinpoint the time of the day with the most shade.
content: Andrew Leavitt can advise couples on where to hold their wedding ceremonies, what hairstyles work best outside or whether to forgo the buttercream frosting on a wedding cake — all based on the weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Ben Shpigel and Gaya Gupta
title: Who is Yevgeny Prigozhin, the mercenary leader Russia accused of mounting a coup?
description: Mr. Prigozhin has risen from a businessman known as President Vladimir V. Putin’s “chef” to a symbol of wartime Russia, controlling a private army operating from Ukraine to Central African Republic.
content: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin became rich through his personal ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, winning lucrative catering and construction contracts with the Russian government while building a mercenary force known as Wagner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: ‘The Impossible Became Possible’: The Women Celebrating a Year Without Roe
description: For anti-abortion activists, the anniversary of the Supreme Court’s decision eliminating the national right to abortion is festive, but also a time to acknowledge challenges.
content: It has been exactly a year since Bethany Bomberger gathered in an impromptu huddle outside a hotel ballroom with fellow anti-abortion activists, overcome with gratitude and optimism as news broke that the Supreme Court had overturned Roe v. Wade just hours before the Pro-Life Women’s Conference officially opened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, June 17-23
description: In pursuit of Queen Bee, it was good to find “king” and hard to find “nankeen.”
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Victor Wembanyama Buzz Has San Antonio Businesses Eager to Cash In
description: The Spurs selected Wembanyama, a French basketball star, No. 1 overall in the N.B.A. draft on Thursday. San Antonio has been celebrating for weeks.
content: Mark Burnett can’t get Victor Wembanyama out of his head. Well, he could, but it would be like taking a knife to the “Mona Lisa.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: If You Can Outrun the Green Flashes, You’ll Set a Record
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 24, 2023.
content: “We used to start running barefoot, then we got shoes, then they got spikes and now they have carbon plates. That’s sport. Now we have a Wavelight, and in 50 years there will be something different again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Debris From Russian Missile Kills Three in Kyiv Apartment Building
description: The capital came under attack as anxiety grew in Russia over a confrontation between Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
content: Russian forces fired more than 20 missiles at Ukraine’s capital in a predawn assault on Saturday that left at least three people dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood Directors Ratify Their Contract as Writers Continue to Strike
description: The vote prevented the doomsday scenario of three major Hollywood unions striking simultaneously. The actors’ union is still negotiating.
content: Unionized movie and television directors approved a new three-year contract with Hollywood studios on Friday, with 87 percent voting in support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tracking the Military Convoys on the Route to Moscow
description: Wagner’s leader announced that his troops marching on Moscow would “turn around.”
content: Military convoys believed to belong to Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s Wagner forces have been seen at various points along Russia’s major M-4 highway, which leads to Moscow. In at least two areas along the route, clashes have broken out. The route shown here is approximate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Georgia Police Department Apologizes for Using Targets With Photo of a Black Man
description: The mayor called for an investigation after the Villa Rica Police Department shared photos of a gun safety training with attendees firing at targets with a photo of a Black man on them.
content: A police department in Georgia apologized this week after its use of firing range targets with photos of a Black man on them at a gun safety class prompted outrage in the community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hadley Heath Manning
title: The Conservative Position on Birth Control Is About Individual Responsibility
description: At the heart of the conservative position on birth control is whether contraception is a positive right or a personal choice.
content: Most Republican voters — 84 percent of them, according to a 2022 poll on behalf of the organization where I work — support safe and accessible birth control. But after Roe v. Wade was overturned last year, Republicans in Congress blocked legislation that would have enshrined a federal right to contraception. And it was Republicans who opposed requiring health insurance policies to cover birth control in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Stymied by Congress, Biden Seeks to Rally Voters on Abortion
description: A year after the end of Roe v. Wade, Biden administration officials are working with a limited set of tools, including executive orders and the bully pulpit, to galvanize supporters.
content: Minutes after the Supreme Court voted to overturn Roe v. Wade last summer, a group of West Wing aides raced to the Oval Office to brief President Biden on the decision. As they drafted a speech, Mr. Biden was the first person in the room to say what has been his administration’s rallying cry ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Tiny Bundles of Hope: Critically Endangered Turtles Hatch in Myanmar
description: Local conservationists at Indawgyi Lake captured the first known videos of rare Burmese peacock turtles hatching.
content: Small miracles are popping out of the mud around Myanmar’s largest lake: Burmese peacock softshell turtles, just hatched from their eggs. For what may be the first time, humans were there to witness the birth of these rare creatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Is That ‘Hava Nagila’ I’m Hearing at the Club?
description: The beloved Jewish folk song, which is about a century old, is appearing more and more at sporting events, private parties and trendy bars.
content: On a Monday afternoon in May, “Hava Nagila,” the infectious Jewish folk song, was reverberating through the Monte-Carlo Beach Club, a resort on the Mediterranean Sea in Monaco. The music was coming from a cliff-side, open-air venue, where revelers dressed in suits and dresses were dancing in circles and swirling cloth napkins in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Short-Lived Mutiny in Russia Sheds Light on Putin’s Hold on Power
description: The armed standoff on the road to Moscow, brief as it was, represented the most dramatic struggle for power in Russia in decades.
content: For more than a year, American officials have quietly asked themselves a question they would not dare pose in public: Could Russia’s botched invasion of Ukraine eventually lead to the downfall of President Vladimir V. Putin?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Ship That Launched Ill-Fated Titan Submersible Returns to Newfoundland
description: Investigators boarded the Polar Prince, which docked at the Atlantic headquarters of the Canadian Coast Guard, looking for answers.
content: Escorted to a Canadian Coast Guard base, the ship that launched the ill-fated Titan submersible returned from international waters to its home port, St. John’s, Newfoundland, on Saturday morning, where investigators boarded it looking for answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pols
title: Family Politics as a Predictor of Mayhem on a Bigger Scale
description: In her new novel, “Little Monsters,” Adrienne Brodeur takes readers on a stressful march toward a patriarch’s 70th birthday party.
content: Adrienne Brodeur’s “Little Monsters” is cleverly calculated to push all the buttons for a wide swath of women. Like her 2019 memoir “Wild Game,” which examined the role Brodeur played in her mother’s long affair with a family friend, “Little Monsters” is a tale of dysfunction and buried secrets, set in and around moneyed Cape Cod.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Paul Ickovic, Photographer at Home on the Street, Dies at 79
description: His camera captured the variety of the human experience, but changing tastes in photography kept him from the acclaim he sought — as did his own idiosyncrasies.
content: Paul Ickovic, a peripatetic photographer whose sensuous black-and-white portraits and evocative images of street life captured in India, Nepal and Cuba, as well as European cities like Paris and Prague, harked back to the heyday of street photography at midcentury, died on May 23 at his home in Prague. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Maiuri
title: What Is Love? For This Fractured Family, the Answer Is Not So Clear.
description: In Thao Thai’s debut novel, “Banyan Moon,” the contentious relationship between a mother and daughter comes to a head when their family’s beloved matriarch dies.
content: In Thao Thai’s debut novel, “Banyan Moon,” Huong Tran, one of the story’s protagonists, confides, “After years of living with my mother, her prudishness and stingy love caging me tight, I longed desperately for something free, something that felt attached to me and no one else.” Feelings of entrapment and spite are prominent in this book, a multi-perspective family saga that chronicles the lives of three Vietnamese women from 1960s Vietnam to present-day Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Extreme Floods and Heat in China Ravage Farms and Kill Animals
description: China’s leader has made it a national priority to ensure the country can feed its large population. But weather shocks have disrupted wheat harvests and threatened pig and fish farming.
content: The downpour began in late May, drenching the wheat crops in central China. As kernels of wheat blackened in the rain, becoming unfit for human consumption, the government mobilized emergency teams to salvage as much of the harvest as possible. In a viral video, a 79-year-old farmer in Henan Province wiped away tears as he surveyed the damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republicans Serve Up Red Meat for a Reason
description: Why haven’t we heard a serious discussion on climate change from G.O.P. candidates?
content: There are, as of Saturday, at least 13 people running for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination: former President Donald Trump; his U.N. ambassador Nikki Haley, his vice president, Mike Pence; Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida; Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota; the former governors Chris Christie of New Jersey and Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas; Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina; the former representative Will Hurd of Texas; Mayor Francis Suarez of Miami; and the entrepreneurs and media personalities Vivek Ramaswamy, Perry Johnson and Larry Elder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: With Reversed Hind Legs and a Loose Tongue, a New Ugly Dog Champion Is Crowned
description: “In the cutest way possible, he kind of reminds me of a hairy hippopotamus,” said Catherine Liang, a judge in the competition.
content: Perhaps it was Scooter’s resemblance to a glossy black jelly bean that earned him the title on Friday night as champion of the World’s Ugliest Dog Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: What to Know About the Election in Sierra Leone
description: In Saturday’s vote, President Julius Maada Bio is seeking a second five-year term to pursue an ambitious if unfulfilled education initiative, while the country is facing a crippling economic crisis.
content: Since he became president of the small West African nation of Sierra Leone in 2018, Julius Maada Bio has dedicated 22 percent of the country’s budget to education, a policy that has sent an additional one million children to school and received attention from international backers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Timeline: What Led to the Standoff Between Russia and Prigozhin
description: The leader of the Wagner mercenary group had kept a low profile for years, only acknowledging his force’s existence in September of last year.
content: For years, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner mercenary leader who conducted a brief rebellion against the Russian military, had been a loyal supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Go Ahead. Debate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
description: If no one contests him publicly, how can the curious be persuaded away from his ideas?
content: In my younger and more vulnerable years, I was asked to fill in for a debate on the shores of Nantucket, after a last-minute cancellation by a more prominent combatant. The subject was God and religion, and I served as defender of faith against the prosecutorial efforts of Christopher Hitchens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Coming Out Late — and Finding a New Life in Midlife
description: Many people, including me, come out in later adulthood. Our stories are not only uplifting but also illuminating and educational.
content: “I’m from Harlem. Born, bred, toasted, buttered, jelly-jammed and honeyed in Harlem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Why Hunter, Britain’s Best Known Wellie, Fell From Grace
description: Blaming supply chains, inflation and changing weather patterns, the Wellington boot brand stumbled toward the brink of extinction this week. Can it be saved by a new (American) owner?
content: For decades, one fashion accessory was more synonymous with Britain’s most famous music festival, Glastonbury, than any other: Hunter Wellington boots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Lessons Learned From a Decade of Answering Your Real Estate Questions
description: In her final entry as The New York Times’s Ask Real Estate columnist, Ronda Kaysen reflects on what it means to give endless advice.
content: Q: For 10 years, Ronda Kaysen answered New Yorkers’ questions each week as The New York Times’s Ask Real Estate columnist. Now, as she shifts her focus to writing more feature articles for The Times, she looks back on what she’s learned. How did she answer the hardest questions and what parting words would she give to anyone seeking housing advice?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: John Williams on ‘Indiana Jones’ and His Favorite Scores
description: In a long career making music for the movies, the composer has made an indelible contribution to cinema. Williams shares his thoughts on some landmark works.
content: When the New York Philharmonic honored the work of the film composer John Williams this past spring, the director Steven Spielberg introduced a clip of the opening scenes of “Raiders of the Lost Ark” — without the music. The effect, he noted apologetically, was like something out of the French new wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell and Todd Heisler
title: In the U.S., an Accomplished Cuban Boxer Takes His First Pro Steps
description: Andy Cruz won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics for Cuba. Now he’s learning to fight like a professional in Philadelphia.
content: When the timer chimed to begin Round 3, Andy Cruz stalked Rostyslav Sabadash behind a stiff jab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Killing of Sikh Leader Raises Fears in British Columbia
description: Members of the Sikh community in Surrey believe that Hardeep Singh Nijjar, the president of a local temple, was killed because of his political views.
content: On Sunday, after riddling a car with bullets in a parking lot, two masked, heavyset men made a run for it and jumped into a getaway vehicle near a Sikh temple in Surrey, British Columbia, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph P. Fried
title: H. Lee Sarokin, Federal Judge Who Freed Hurricane Carter, Dies at 94
description: In his 15 years on the U.S. District Court bench in Newark, he also ruled on high-profile cases involving the tobacco industry and the rights of homeless people.
content: H. Lee Sarokin, who as a federal judge in New Jersey overturned the triple-murder conviction of the star boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, voided a public library’s ban against a homeless man and angered cigarette companies that claimed he had shown bias against them, died on Tuesday in the La Jolla section of San Diego, where he and his wife, Margie, lived in retirement. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google News Blocked in Russia as Feud With Mercenary Leader Intensifies
description: At least five telecommunications companies have blocked the service, which aggregates news from various sources, according to an analysis from NetBlocks, an internet observatory.
content: Several Russian internet service providers are preventing users inside the country from accessing Google News after Russian generals accused a mercenary leader, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, of attempting a coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: Greetings, People of Earth
description: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: The Hollywood Producer Who Could Bring Down Israel’s Netanyahu
description: Arnon Milchan, the movie mogul, billionaire spy and old friend of Benjamin Netanyahu, is about to testify at the Israeli prime minister’s corruption trial.
content: The life story of Arnon Milchan, billionaire Hollywood mogul and secret agent, could have been made for the silver screen: He produced blockbusters like “Pretty Woman,” “Mr. & Mrs. Smith” and “Bohemian Rhapsody,” and also made a fortune from arms dealing, including covert exploits procuring weapons for Israel, his native country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Kyle Crichton
title: As Putin’s Trusted Partner, Prigozhin Was Always Willing to Do the Dirty Work
description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the mercenary leader of the Wagner Group, had earned the trust of Vladimir V. Putin. Then he staged a mutiny that rattled the Kremlin.
content: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the mercenary leader who led an armed rebellion in Russia on Saturday, was never afraid of a dirty task, many say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim and Iman Al-Dabbagh
title: Saudi Arabia Wants Tourists. It Didn’t Expect Christians.
description: In a fluid new age for the conservative Islamic kingdom, evangelicals have become some of its most enthusiastic visitors.
content: The caravan of five Toyota Land Cruisers raced across Saudi Arabia’s rocky desert, weaving onto a highway so new it was not on the map. At the cleft of sea that splits the kingdom from Egypt, they stopped on a barren beach. Fifteen tourists spilled out and gathered around Joel Richardson, a Kansas preacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Five Things to Know One Year After the Dobbs Decision
description: The Supreme Court ruling that overturned Roe v. Wade has produced some unexpected legal and political changes, as well as a shift in public opinion.
content: In the year since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, some of the results of the decision have been unsurprising — more than a dozen Republican-led states have moved to ban most abortions, and dozens of abortion clinics have closed. Yet there have also been unexpected legal and political changes that have left Americans on both sides of the issue scrambling to adapt. Here are five major changes detailed in The New York Times’s coverage of the first anniversary of the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, which ended the constitutional right to abortion after nearly 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Opposites Attracting
description: John Westwig delivers a Sunday puzzle that’s simply dazzling.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David S. Cohen, Greer Donley and Rachel Rebouché
title: We Need to Talk About Overturning the Dobbs Decision
description: It won’t be easy, and it probably won’t be quick. But there needs to be a plan in place.
content: The end of Roe v. Wade spawned a momentous realignment of abortion politics and legal strategy in the United States. Almost a third of states in this country now ban almost all abortions, while more than a third have passed new laws protecting abortion rights — with many legal battles playing out in state and federal courtrooms. The issue has dominated elections, from surprise ballot initiative results in red states to an anomalous midterm election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 24, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 24, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about President Biden’s attempt to bolster ties with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India incorrectly characterized Mr. Modi’s joint news conference with Mr. Biden. It was a rare instance of Mr. Modi taking questions from reporters at a news conference during his nine years leading India, but not the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: In N.Y. Primaries, Democrats Face a Swell of Challengers From the Right
description: The Queens district attorney and several City Council members face more conservative challengers who are criticizing them on issues including public safety.
content: When Melinda Katz ran for Queens district attorney in 2019, her principal opponent in the Democratic primary was a public defender and democratic socialist with a platform of ending cash bail and eventually abolishing the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin embraced turmoil, and now it is rattling his leadership.
description: For more than two decades, the system helped President Vladimir V. Putin secure his unrivaled authority, ensuring that he personally held the keys to wealth and influence in modern Russia.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia always seemed to thrive on chaos. Then it threatened to consume him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: I Thought No One Had Felt Grief Like Mine. Then I Saw ‘The Bear.’
description: A lot of television shows portray the experience of grieving. But after my own tragic experience, only “The Bear” felt authentic to me.
content: The pilot episode of “The Bear,” FX’s frenetic series about a high-end chef who takes over his family’s blue-collar sandwich shop, opens with an unsettling image. In the dead of night in Chicago, a man in an apron — we later learn that this is Carmen (Carmy) Berzatto, played by Jeremy Allen White, the series’s main character — walks over a fog-enshrouded bridge, cautiously approaching a large cage. Inside it, something is growling. The man swings the door open wide and confronts a great, angry bear. At first, he tries to soothe the beast, whispering, “I know.” But the bear lunges at him. The man wakes — it’s a dream and, we suspect, not the first time he’s had it — and heads off to face the suffocating anxiety that marks his daily life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: U.S. Government Moves to Expand Health Care to Pacific Veterans
description: Citizens of three Pacific Island nations, eligible to serve in the U.S. military, have faced a Catch-22 in gaining access to certain benefits. That may change soon.
content: After decades of neglect, the U.S. government is one step closer to eliminating longstanding obstacles to free health care for veterans from three Pacific Island nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Issie Lapowsky
title: The Race to Prevent ‘the Worst Case Scenario for Machine Learning’
description: A.I. companies have an edge in blocking the creation and distribution of child sexual abuse material. They’ve seen how social media companies failed.
content: Dave Willner has had a front-row seat to the evolution of the worst things on the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: This City Had Quietly Celebrated Pride Before. In 2023, That Was Not an Option.
description: After right-wing activists portrayed a Pride event in Franklin, Tenn., as a threat to children, the small city unexpectedly found itself at the center of a backlash.
content: As dozens of cars snaked their way onto the grounds of a refurbished horse farm on a sweltering June afternoon in Franklin, Tenn., a few volunteers stood at the entrance, cheerfully welcoming visitors to the local Pride festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Is Our DJ Now. It’s Playing a Lot of Meghan Trainor.
description: The video app drives streams on Spotify and influences the Billboard charts. Years after she broke through as a musician, the singer is gaining new fans, one viral dance soundtrack at a time.
content: Meghan Trainor, the pop star, is sitting in an empty marble bathtub, fully clothed and flanked by two of her friends. The three of them begin soulfully crooning an a cappella version of “Made You Look,” the hit single Ms. Trainor released in the fall, nailing every note for about half a minute. Then they stop, look at one another and scream with delight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Three San Antonio Police Officers Charged With Murder in Woman’s Shooting Death
description: The officers fired at Melissa Perez after responding to a call outside her home.
content: Three San Antonio police officers were charged with murder on Friday after police shot and killed a 46-year-old woman, who swung a hammer in their direction and appeared to be in distress, in her home, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dmitriy Khavin, Sarah Kerr, Riley Mellen and Muyi Xiao
title: Wagner Chief Prigozhin Appears in Videos at a Russian Military Headquarters
description: The head of the mercenary group claimed to have control of parts of the complex in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don.
content: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the mercenary Wagner group, claimed to have control of several important military facilities in southern Russia in the city of Rostov-on-Don. Video verified by The New York Times shows that he had entered a key military complex on Saturday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Religious Controversies on Many Fronts in the U.S.
description: Readers discuss ordaining women, separation of church and state, and Christian nationalism.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greek Youths, Shaped by Debt Crisis, Plan to Vote for Stability
description: Many children of Greece’s traumatic years of economic collapse have opted for pragmatism over radicalism and say they will back a conservative on Sunday.
content: Days before this Sunday’s election in Greece, three young women with piercings and ironic T-shirts who sat outside a hipster coffee shop in an Athens neighborhood best known as a hub of anarchist fervor said they wanted stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Scientists Debut Lab Models of Human Embryos
description: Four teams have coaxed human stem cells to organize themselves into embryo-like forms. The advance could shed light on fertility.
content: In its first week, a fertilized human egg develops into a hollow ball of 200 cells and then implants itself on the wall of the uterus. Over the next three weeks, it divides into the distinct tissues of a human body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: After Extra Large Rate Increase, Bank of England’s Critics Multiply
description: Pressure is building in Britain for the bank’s governor, Andrew Bailey, to show that policymakers have a handle on the inflation problem.
content: “Mortgage misery for millions.” “Rate rise nightmare.” These were just two of the grim headlines on Britain’s front pages taking aim at the Bank of England on Friday, the day after it announced a surprisingly large increase in interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Line on a Map?
description: Spencer Leach and Quiara Vasquez combine forces on a scintillating Saturday challenge.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This crossword represents the meeting of two minds that we first encountered earlier this year in sparkling debut puzzles. Quiara Vasquez shared a byline with Dan Ziring on a popular themed Thursday grid in January; Spencer Leach’s first effort was a witty Saturday one from just six weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Save Turner Classic Movies
description: Movies from the past shape our present.
content: WASHINGTON — I co-starred with Sir Alec Guinness in a movie where a submersible travels down to the Titanic, springs a leak and implodes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marzano-Lesnevich
title: How Did a $2 Billion Trove of Art End Up in a Random Attic in France?
description: In a new book, Michael Finkel tells the story of Stéphane Breitwieser, “perhaps the most successful and prolific art thief who has ever lived.”
content: At first, Stéphane Breitwieser, the subject of Michael Finkel’s “The Art Thief,” appears to be having an enviable amount of fun. Twenty-five years old and living with his girlfriend, Anne-Catherine Kleinklaus, in a small set of upstairs rooms in his mother’s home in a “hardscrabble” manufacturing suburb in eastern France, Breitwieser is unburdened by such quotidian concerns as a job, making rent or planning for the future. He fancies himself a purer sort of soul, so devoted to beauty he must, in Finkel’s words, “gorge on it.” Over the course of a dizzying 200 pages that are also an effective advertisement for Swiss Army knives (Breitwieser’s only tool), he removes artwork after artwork from museums — a.k.a. “prisons for art” — and becomes “perhaps the most successful and prolific art thief who has ever lived.” He piled all $2 billion worth of artifacts he amassed over eight years into that same attic in his mother Mireille Stengel’s “nondescript” stucco house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: How a Crypto Fugitive Upended the Politics of a Troubled Balkan Nation
description: Only days before an election in Montenegro, a letter from Do Kwon, the fugitive founder of the Luna digital coin, claimed that crypto “friends” had provided campaign funding to a leading candidate.
content: Already notorious as an agent of market mayhem, the crypto industry has now unleashed political havoc, too, upending a critical general election in Montenegro, a troubled Balkan nation struggling to shake off the grip of organized crime and the influence of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: Crisis in Russia
description: A Russian mercenary leader claimed he controls a military headquarters in southern Russia, and Vladimir Putin vowed to take action.
content: A long-running feud over the invasion of Ukraine between the Russian military and Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of Russia’s private Wagner military group, escalated into an open confrontation over the past day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nagourney and Mike Ives
title: What’s happening in Russia? Here’s what we know.
description: A powerful mercenary chief sent his forces on the move against the Russian military establishment, raising tensions in the country to a level not seen in decades.
content: A powerful mercenary military leader brought in by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to help salvage his floundering invasion of Ukraine turned his guns on the Russian Army this weekend, and his tanks prowled the streets of his own country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: ‘Padam Padam’: You Hear It and You Know It’s Pride
description: Kylie Minogue’s latest single appears to be on the fast track to gay-classic status. We asked D.J.s booked for Pride events to weigh in on the track’s devoted cult following.
content: When “Padam Padam,” the Australian pop star Kylie Minogue’s 77th (77th!) single, was released last month, it was embraced almost instantaneously by a certain type of listener. L.G.B.T.Q. people, especially gay men, greeted the campy song with gleeful incredulity, and its infectious chorus quickly spawned memes upon memes upon memes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill and Caroline Kim
title: Pride’s Last Chance in a Tennessee City
description: Last year, drag shows at the Franklin, Tenn., Pride celebration turned into a national scandal. We followed a teenage member of Franklin Pride’s board during this year’s embattled process of throwing a small-town Pride festival.
content: Last year, drag shows at the Franklin, Tenn., Pride celebration turned into a national scandal. We followed a teenage member of Franklin Pride’s board during this year’s embattled process of throwing a small-town Pride festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dmitriy Khavin and Sarah Kerr
title: Video Shows Wagner Fighters Surrounding Military Headquarters
description: Men in military uniforms, whom filmers and bystanders identified as Wagner fighters, surrounded and then occupied a Russian military headquarters compound in the city of Rostov-on-Don on June 24.
content: Men in military uniforms, whom filmers and bystanders identified as Wagner fighters, surrounded and then occupied a Russian military headquarters compound in the city of Rostov-on-Don on June 24.
source.name: The New York Times
